Charles Young was born March H. 1854 Mayslick Kentucky


soldier. He taught first his grandmother and
then in the public school Ripley Ohio where his family had moved
when he nine months At the Of sixteen finished
high school education alone,
sincerely interested in learning and knowing the truth

and discussed with him the questions and problems OF the day.

The first meeting called by Mayor Milton

ia cling the large SouthSide area could be rated
as a good beginning.


Judging from the number Of interested per-
sons aOho attended, no one can doubt the zeal
which is present I'M the area.

GRITTY.

ticians and citizens, inchldi,ag Pre- sident John

the Plans


The Worlds Fair would haze been an en-
cellent time for the progress Of the AmeTi-
can Negro to haze been bubHcized. The at
tempt to haze Emancipation Centennial
exhibit at Mccormick Place in Chicago last
year could haze been an excelle addition
to the grand vieaOS awaiting visitoYs to the
fair.


Much more could haze been done to promote
understanding and expand knowledge Of the
American Negro by utilizing space at the
Worlds Fair. This would haze been OeH worth
the money W0Sted on the exhibit at Chicago.


An exhibit at the fair would haze been seen
by persons Wlao could haze realized that deS-
bite the ineQuities in this country Negroes
haze and are continuing to progress.

This month is called Teaching
Career Month. AS a teacher
often wonder who Is the teacher7
Sometimes | am on the brink
of wringing my hands and clench-
ing my lip in disgust when |
m unable to get some concept
across to my 43 pupils. But, at
that last minute-somehow spark
comes and they grasp the fact
or solve the problem.


Who was taught them was.
Surely no teacher ever feels that
he or she has the magin formula
to teach all pupils who face them
from year to year. However, |
believe that more children might
learn if the schools respected
their willingness to learn bit
more.


There are thousands Of chill
dren might learn If the schools
respected their willingness to
learn bit more.


There are thousands of chill
dren who are unable to learn
simply because no one takes time
to find their particular interest.
No one child may want to read the
same book. No one child may
want to draw at the same time
as his classmates.


One day l opened up bag which
contained some oyster shells. My
husband had Toasted several
nights before on the oysters.
AS we opened them on the drain
board--I told him that | would
keep them for my class.


Never suspecting that half
dozen shells could stimulate so
uch interest--I walked in with
plittle brown bag.


You can not imagine the move
ant and conversation these low
ly shells caused. We handled
them we rubbed them. We
smelled them, we traced them and
we read about them. Encycloped-
las we're brought out. Science
textbooks and even magazines
we're located with shell pictures.


The next day several pupils
brought some shells from home
and we had a grand time dis
covering the kinds Of animals
that lived in our oceans.


During a trip to the Bahama
Islands my husband had brought
a two shells. had never taken
time to learn what kind they we're.
One Of my pupils found a pic
rure Of my shells In a nature
study booklet.


With satisfaction on his face,
he rushed to my desk saying he
had found out about our mystery
shells.


We may live far away from
the ocean, but somehow the ocean
is very near. Teaching is just
as near as the teacher cares to
lead. | have learned a lot since
we started our unit on the ocean.
l have not taught all that | ex-
pected. l never do.


do not have the cures for our
teaching ills. only know that
better prepared teachers and
ore dedicated teachers will
provide better teaching. We need
more ways to keep pupil atten-
tion. Some need art, some need
singing, some need poetry. some
need phonics, some need history,
some need baseball, some need
sewing and some need language.


All need just little more
understanding and little more
heading in the right direction.

Siuhts and Sounds
ELoIsE BANKS
Still Learn ing
